ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was great! My writing improved tremendously because of Professor Forsters guidance. His line editing is incredible and really forces you to think about the meaning behind every word that you write. That level of care and attention is almost indescribable!

I left this course with a much wider knowledge of the kinds of films made by Black artists. Prior to taking this class, I had a very narrow conception of what Black film is. Now I feel like I have a better understanding of what can be considered a Black film, and the many generes that can be included in it.
Exposure to Black films and discussion about what Black film means, as well as the themes that come up throughout the films
We learned about the history of Black film by watching films, analyzing them, and reading a variety of scholarship, articles, interviews, etc. about the films and Black film theory.

In this course, I was able to explore something that I never had before, and I'm glad I got this opportunity to expand my knowledge and curiosity! We learned a lot about thinking in a more detailed fashion as well as keeping our minds open.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is genuinely great! I love being able to sit and talk with my peers about the readings and the films we watched, especially with everybody having such diverse backgrounds. I only wish the class was longer so our conversations could be deeper.

I think the selection of films and readings for this course is very strong. However, one thing I think could be improved are our class discussions. I think that having a more concrete lesson for the day, rather than so much student discussion, could increase how much is taken away from the course.

Really interesting films and discussions, just lacked a little bit of direction in our learning. I would've preferred slightly less reading so that we could go further into specific topics in class rather than having a more tenuous grasp on lots of different ideas. Additionally, the seminars could've had more structure so it was clearer what we were supposed to get out of each class. But overall I really enjoyed the things we talked about and viewed.
Discussion over zoom is sometimes difficult. Breakout rooms allowed more freedom to work through ideas with a few classmates and were helpful in figuring out what to say in the main discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall pretty good - I just find seminars difficult over zoom, so I would've liked a little bit more structure within each class.
Breakout rooms could be incorporated more. I didn't feel that Perusall helped me understand the reading more.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Please take this class if you can! This is genuinely one of the best classes Ive ever taken at Yale! Beyond the desire to simply get a good grade, this is the one of the first classes where I actually felt like I learned something. It wasnt just doing the reading and writing papers to get an A, it was effort put into understanding every word and theory, every film. So much of what I learned in this course, especially the processes, have completely changed the way I approach readings and papers. Thats never going to leave and Im a better student for having taken this course!

Yes, but only if you are committed to doing the work. It is geared more towards film majors than I expected an introductory course to be, so I would not recommend it if you are not particularly invested in the material.

I would highly recommend this course to anybody interested in film or AfAm studies. You watch a lot excellent and interesting films that the core FMS courses don't screen and learn important things about race and art.
Yes. Again, I really liked how much this course was able to expand how I think, and Professor Forster is absolutely wonderful and super nice and helpful!

Yes!! The films and readings in this course are great and Prof. Forster is fantastic. He cares so much about his students and is very open to helping increase student engagement and learning in any ways he can. I took this course during covid-19 and that made for a more difficult seminar-setting, but I still thoroughly enjoyed this material and grew as a Film Studies student through it.
